summary: choose 2 for each category: all the avengers; batman/flash/green arrow/wonder woman/aquaman/superman
question: choose 2 for each category: all the avengers; batman/flash/green arrow/wonder woman/aquaman/superman
answer:
Avengers: Meh. Probably Captain America and Spider-man. 

Justice League: Of the ones you’ve listed, Wonder Woman and Flash, though it feels weird to say considering my current obsession with Batfam fanfic.

tags: peter being a gen z kid
summary:
Tony: hey Kid, you want anything to eat?
Peter: yes Mr Stark can I have some t i d e p o d s?
Tony: What the fuck- no, Peter....
body:
Tony: hey Kid, you want anything to eat?

Peter: yes Mr Stark can I have some t i d e p o d s?

Tony: What the fuck- no, Peter. Alright, let’s try again. You want a drink?

Peter: I’m thinking some healthy b l e a c h

Tony: Jesus Christ

summary: The DVD of Infinity War came out today and it is pure gold. On one side, you have Tony and right on the other, you have Steve....
body: The DVD of Infinity War came out today and it is pure gold. On one side, you have Tony and right on the other, you have Steve. This symmetry is amazing. They were both almost on opposite sides of the universe, fighting for their lives and the whole universe. Even though they were not together in the movie, together, they make the Avengers. It actually made me tear up.

It actually made me tear up.

summary: Losing It All Was Never So Easy - Chapter 1 - Starculler - Young Justice (Cartoon) [Archive of Our Own]
title: Losing It All Was Never So Easy - Chapter 1 - Starculler - Young Justice (Cartoon) [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
Chapters: 2/7
Fandom: Young Justice (Cartoon), Batman - All Media Types, The Avengers (Marvel) - All Media Types
Rating: Teen And Up Audiences
Warnings: Graphic Depictions Of Violence
Characters: Dick Grayson, Peter Parker, Tony Stark, Steve Rogers
Additional Tags: Kidnapping, Crossovers & Fandom Fusions, Implied/Referenced Brainwashing, Implied/Referenced Torture, Alternate Universe - Canon Divergence
Summary:

Captured and sold to the highest bidder by the Light, Robin (Dick Grayson) is the latest in a long series of projects to overthrow the heroes. He needs to find a way out of this hellhole and back home to Gotham, but that might be harder than just hopping a train or using a phone.

blog.name: esonetwork
blog.title: The ESO Network
blog.description: From its beginnings in April 2010, the ESO Network is the Podcast network of shows that celebrate our love for all things pop culture, sci-fi and fantasy, comics, and much, much more. Join Podcasts like Earth Station One, Earth Station Who, Doctor Geek’s Laboratory for Applied Science, Transmissions From Atlantis, The White Rocket, The Thirteenth Hour, and The Ratchet Retrocast (more shows to come) as we dive headfirst into the world of their favorite topics, and see what they can find to get into trouble with! Stop by for a listen and let your inner geek out to play.

summary: ‘Best of the worst’: Top five Marvel Cinematic Universe villains
title: ‘Best of the worst’: Top five Marvel Cinematic Universe villains
body:
New Post has been published on https://esopodcast.com/best-of-the-worst-top-five-marvel-cinematic-universe-villains/

‘Best of the worst’: Top five Marvel Cinematic Universe villains

After an epic 10-year buildup, the Marvel Cinematic Universe’s ultimate villain finally arrived to restore balance to the universe earlier this summer. Thanos was, at least for me, worth the wait, and I’m looking forward to watching him in “Infinity War” again, now that this movie is coming out on DVD and Blu-ray today.

Few franchises have been able to match the success of the MCU, or its impressive cast of well-loved superheroes. However, it’s fair to say that the track record for the MCU’s villains hasn’t been quite as strong. For a while, in terms of strong villains, there was Loki…and…well…it was pretty much just Loki.

That’s been improving in recent MCU history, so in honor of “Infinity War” coming out, here are my top five MCU villains — and I’d love to hear yours as well! (Note: I didn’t include the Marvel Netflix shows, but if I had, Kingpin, Kilgrave, Cottonmouth, and Mariah Dillard would have taken up most of the slots on this list.) 

Honorable mention: Hela

I LOVED Cate Blanchett in this role, and you could tell she had a blast playing an MCU villain. The only reason she misses the top five is because of an issue I have with “Thor: Ragnarok” overall. It’s a really funny movie, but it’s almost *too* funny. The more emotional and serious moments are glossed over a little too quickly, so Hela doesn’t carry the same pathos as, say, Loki in the MCU movies.

5. Ego

Even though the revelation that Ego was the film’s true villain wasn’t a major surprise, I found it super interesting that the Guardians movies, which are all about family, featured a villain who was a family member of one of the main characters. Kurt Russell is such a likable guy that it’s hard to hate the character, until you realize what terrible things he has done. He also helps Peter realize that even though the other Guardians may not be related to him, they are Peter’s true family.

4. Killmonger

Although Killmonger’s methods were (obviously) wrong, what made him a compelling villain was the fact he was asking some important questions about racism and responsibility that needed to be asked. He proved to be a key foil for Black Panther as T’Challa developed his own leadership philosophy and shaped Wakanda’s future. There’s a lot going on in “Black Panther,” and I almost wish they had cut a few characters and tightened the plot a little to get even more time with Killmonger. Still, a great performance from Michael B. Jordan.

3. Vulture

Vulture is definitely the smallest-scale villain on this list, which is actually why I really like him. Michael Keaton has a very down-to-earth take on the role; Vulture isn’t an over-the-top villain who has a bunch of superpowers and wants to take over the world. He’s just a regular guy trying to take care of his family, and then ends up going down the wrong path. The fact he’s such a believable character is what makes him even scarier.

2. Thanos

It feels weird not putting Thanos in the No. 1 spot — he really is the ultimate MCU villain, and I’m super curious to see what happens with the character in “Infinity War” part 2. Although I love the character in my No. 1 spot just a *little* bit more, I appreciated that the film makers gave Thanos more nuance than I was expecting. He was a fascinating character, and I liked that the film really dug into the motivations behind his actions. He definitely lived up to the 10 years of hype, at least for me.

1. Loki

At this point in the MCU, is Loki even really a villain?  He’s probably more of an antihero, but I just love Tom Hiddleston’s performance as this character. Loki is funny and charming, but there’s a bit of tragedy running underneath the surface. Loki feels like a bit of an outsider in Asgard, and he resents living in his adopted brother Thor’s shadow. As sad as it was to see Loki go in “Infinity War,” I hope that’s one of the MCU deaths that sticks, because I thought it was a good end for the character.

And, as a bonus, here are the top 5 Marvel villains that most need improvement (counting down from “sort of okay” to “definite missed opportunity”). My “worst of the worst” list, I guess you could say? 

5. Kaecilius

I actually really love the look of this character and how he fits into “Doctor Strange’s” overall aesthetic as a film. But I felt he didn’t have enough character depth, and there’s so much more they could have done with him as a character.

4. Ivan Vanko

I don’t think Vanko was a bad MCU villain per se; he just doesn’t particularly stand out, either. Tony Stark has fought better villains that are better foils for his character.

3. Yellowjacket

Although “Ant-Man” is one of my favorite MCU films, Yellowjacket feels more like a generic superhero movie villain, who is more just there to drive the plot forward.

2. Ronan the Accuser

Ah, Ronan. He actually doesn’t bother me that much, because the rest of “Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 1” is so awesome. But he still feels like a bit of a missed opportunity to do something even cooler with the character.

1. Malekith the Dark Elf

I don’t really remember much about this character from “Thor: The Dark World” (Loki pretty much steals that movie, anyway). Like Ronan, Malekith feels like a missed opportunity, especially since I was excited to see “Doctor Who” alum Christopher Eccleston in an MCU film.

So, what are your favorite (and least favorite) MCU villains?

2. Ronan the Accuser

Few franchises have been able to match the success of the MCU, or its impressive cast of well-loved superheroes. However, it’s fair to say that the track record for the MCU’s villains hasn’t been quite as strong. For a while, in terms of strong villains, there was Loki…and…well…it was pretty much just Loki.

That’s been improving in recent MCU history, so in honor of “Infinity War” coming out, here are my top five MCU villains — and I’d love to hear yours as well! (Note: I didn’t include the Marvel Netflix shows, but if I had, Kingpin, Kilgrave, Cottonmouth, and Mariah Dillard would have taken up most of the slots on this list.) 

External image

Honorable mention: Hela

I LOVED Cate Blanchett in this role, and you could tell she had a blast playing an MCU villain. The only reason she misses the top five is because of an issue I have with “Thor: Ragnarok” overall. It’s a really funny movie, but it’s almost *too* funny. The more emotional and serious moments are glossed over a little too quickly, so Hela doesn’t carry the same pathos as, say, Loki in the MCU movies.

External image

5. Ego

Even though the revelation that Ego was the film’s true villain wasn’t a major surprise, I found it super interesting that the Guardians movies, which are all about family, featured a villain who was a family member of one of the main characters. Kurt Russell is such a likable guy that it’s hard to hate the character, until you realize what terrible things he has done. He also helps Peter realize that even though the other Guardians may not be related to him, they are Peter’s true family.

External image

4. Killmonger

Although Killmonger’s methods were (obviously) wrong, what made him a compelling villain was the fact he was asking some important questions about racism and responsibility that needed to be asked. He proved to be a key foil for Black Panther as T’Challa developed his own leadership philosophy and shaped Wakanda’s future. There’s a lot going on in “Black Panther,” and I almost wish they had cut a few characters and tightened the plot a little to get even more time with Killmonger. Still, a great performance from Michael B. Jordan.

External image

3. Vulture

Vulture is definitely the smallest-scale villain on this list, which is actually why I really like him. Michael Keaton has a very down-to-earth take on the role; Vulture isn’t an over-the-top villain who has a bunch of superpowers and wants to take over the world. He’s just a regular guy trying to take care of his family, and then ends up going down the wrong path. The fact he’s such a believable character is what makes him even scarier.

External image

2. Thanos

It feels weird not putting Thanos in the No. 1 spot — he really is the ultimate MCU villain, and I’m super curious to see what happens with the character in “Infinity War” part 2. Although I love the character in my No. 1 spot just a *little* bit more, I appreciated that the film makers gave Thanos more nuance than I was expecting. He was a fascinating character, and I liked that the film really dug into the motivations behind his actions. He definitely lived up to the 10 years of hype, at least for me.

External image

1. Loki

At this point in the MCU, is Loki even really a villain? 

External image
 He’s probably more of an antihero, but I just love Tom Hiddleston’s performance as this character. Loki is funny and charming, but there’s a bit of tragedy running underneath the surface. Loki feels like a bit of an outsider in Asgard, and he resents living in his adopted brother Thor’s shadow. As sad as it was to see Loki go in “Infinity War,” I hope that’s one of the MCU deaths that sticks, because I thought it was a good end for the character.

External image

And, as a bonus, here are the top 5 Marvel villains that most need improvement (counting down from “sort of okay” to “definite missed opportunity”). My “worst of the worst” list, I guess you could say? 
External image

5. Kaecilius

I actually really love the look of this character and how he fits into “Doctor Strange’s” overall aesthetic as a film. But I felt he didn’t have enough character depth, and there’s so much more they could have done with him as a character.

External image

4. Ivan Vanko

I don’t think Vanko was a bad MCU villain per se; he just doesn’t particularly stand out, either. Tony Stark has fought better villains that are better foils for his character.

External image

3. Yellowjacket

Although “Ant-Man” is one of my favorite MCU films, Yellowjacket feels more like a generic superhero movie villain, who is more just there to drive the plot forward.

External image

2. Ronan the Accuser

Ah, Ronan. He actually doesn’t bother me that much, because the rest of “Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 1” is so awesome. But he still feels like a bit of a missed opportunity to do something even cooler with the character.

External image

1. Malekith the Dark Elf

I don’t really remember much about this character from “Thor: The Dark World” (Loki pretty much steals that movie, anyway). Like Ronan, Malekith feels like a missed opportunity, especially since I was excited to see “Doctor Who” alum Christopher Eccleston in an MCU film.

External image

So, what are your favorite (and least favorite) MCU villains?

blog.name: wehavebackissuesblog
blog.title: We Have Back Issues
blog.description: two friends explore the back catalog of Marvel comics, one mullet at a time

summary: Fan Theory  Professor X was Homophobic (... and that is why Juggernaut hated him) Wait, What?! Our theory is that when they were...
body:
Fan Theory

Professor X was Homophobic

(… and that is why Juggernaut hated him)

Wait, What?!

Our theory is that when they were younger, Charles Xavier discovered that his step brother Cain Marko was bisexual. Xavier revealed this information to their step father. As a result Cain was abused by his father and terrified/resentful of Xavier. Like many LGBTQ+ youth, Cain repeatedly tried to escape his home life. Cain finally succeeded and traveled the world as a mercenary. Later, when they served in the military together, Cain deserted because he was afraid that Charles would reveal his secret to their unit.

But Wasn’t Xavier Like a Saint?

  • Xavier used his telepathy for personal gain.
  • He used his telepathy on his family.
  • He used his telepathy to erase memories from the minds of his own team.
  • Xavier enslaved a sentient being.
  • Xavier was an absentee father.
  • Xavier was a serial liar.

So Juggernaut is Bisexual?

Yes! While Juggernaut has had a brief tryst with She-Hulk, His longest running and most important relationship is with fellow mercenary Black Tom Cassidy. While it is never explicitly stated that they are in a sexual relationship, their behavior is heavily suggestive that their relationship is more that platonic. Both men are extremely protective of the other, and for super villains that are otherwise motivated by only self interest, both men go out of their way to save the other, often at great personal expense. It is especially important to note that Juggernaut, a man possessed by a God of Destruction, often leaves a fight to save Tom’s life.

Okay, So Juggernaut is Bisexual, but that doesn’t make Xavier homophobic.

Isn’t it a bit strange that on the wildly diverse X-Men not a single member was openly gay under Xavier’s tenure? Also as a telepath Xaviefr must have known that Iceman was in the closet. Did he counsel Iceman? Did he show support by recruiting other openly gay X-Men? No he let’s Iceman believe that his sexuality is best kept a secret. Best case scenario, Charles felt such guilt about his treatment of his brother that he saw himself as unequiped to adequately provide guidance to his student.

trail.content:
by hitokiridarkempress

After all the grief Stephen and Tony put them through. It’s only fitting they get to ruin their days too.

or

blog.description: Just a feed for Ironstrange fics! Send an ask for recs or if youre looking for a specific fic :)

title: Home
description:
by TumbleTree

“Yeah, sounds great!” He yelled, running back into the living room, just in time to see Mr. Stark pull away from Strange. Peter paused in the entrance way and gave the cloak a meaningful look. Which he was pretty sure it returned from its place by the elevator.

He was definitely going to look into whatever that was.

___________________

Five times Tony and Stephen acted like a married couple with Peter, and one time they did it on their own.
